of Medicine and Health","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHSL2101 - Physiology 1A","description":"

This course introduces students to fundamental physiological principles, from basic cellular function in terms of chemical and physical principles to the operation and interaction of body systems. Although introductory in the level of content, this course in Human Physiology is comprehensive in scope covering a range of body systems from a cellular to a more integrative approach.  The areas of physiology covered in this - course are excitable tissues (cell physiology), muscle, the cardiovascular system, blood and neuroscience. The course includes a substantial series of practical class experiments in which students work in small groups to conduct experiments that give a deeper insight into these specific topic areas, and an appreciation of how the results of experiments depend not only on what we measure but how we measure it.  Online self-directed activities and practical classes further support the course content and learning objectives. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"606dba84dbf57c90be4672f5f39619ae","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online tutorials","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Online tutorials support each of the areas of physiology covered in this course.  

These tutorials serve to summarise key concepts and knowledge of lecture topics covered in the course.  Quiz questions are incorporated into the tutorials and students will receive immediate feedback on submitted answers. Assessment grades for this activity are awarded for completion of the tutorials with a minimum score of 90% for the quiz questions incorporated within the tutorials. The tutorials are to be done in student’s own time and can be attempted multiple times to improve scores.   

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"606dba84dbf57c90be4672f5f39619af","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"206dba84dbf57c90be4672f5f39619b9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Post lab revision modules","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Post-lab revision modules support each of the laboratory practical classes.  These modules help students appreciate the key approaches, results and conclusions of the practical class.  The modules contain embedded quiz questions with immediate feedback provided on the submitted answers. Assessment grades for this activity are awarded for completion of the modules with a minimum score of 90% for the quiz questions incorporated within the modules. The modules are to be done in the student’s own time and can be attempted multiple times to improve scores.   

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"686dba84dbf57c90be4672f5f39619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"686dba84dbf57c90be4672f5f39619af","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6c6dba84dbf57c90be4672f5f39619b1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-session Theory Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

The mid-session exam will consist of MCQs and short answer questions related to topics covered in the first half of the course. The format is the same as the final exam. Feedback is provided through grades and model answers released to students following assessment. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"606dba84dbf57c90be4672f5f39619af","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"686dba84dbf57c90be4672f5f39619af","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e46dba84dbf57c90be4672f5f39619b5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"End of session exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

The end of session exam is in two Parts. Part 1 covers material from the Practical Classes throughout the whole course. Part 1 is comprised of MCQs and is worth 25%. Part 2 will consist of MCQs and short answer questions related to topics covered in the second half of the course.  Part 2 is worth 35%. Feedback is provided through a final course grade.

A","description":"

This course introduces students to fundamental physiological principles, from basic cellular function in terms of chemical and physical principles to the operation and interaction of body systems. Although introductory in the level of content, this course in Human Physiology is comprehensive in scope covering a range of body systems from a cellular to a more integrative approach.  The areas of physiology covered in this course are excitable tissues (cell physiology), muscle, the cardiovascular system, blood and neuroscience. The course includes a substantial series of practical class experiments in which students work in small groups to conduct experiments that give a deeper insight into these specific topic areas, and an appreciation of how the results of experiments depend not only on what we measure but how we measure it.  Online self-directed activities and practical classes further support the course content and learning objectives. 


Note: Restricted to students enrolled in the Biomedical Engineering double degree programs.

The end of session exam is in two Parts. Part 1 covers material from the Practical Classes throughout the whole course. Part 1 is comprised of MCQs and is worth 25%. Part 2 will consist of MCQs and short answer questions related to topics covered in the second half of the course.  Part 2 is worth 35%. Feedback is provided through a final course grade.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e29dbec4dbf57c90be4672f5f3961992","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ea9dbec4dbf57c90be4672f5f3961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ea9dbec4dbf57c90be4672f5f3961992","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"269dbec4dbf57c90be4672f5f3961998","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Post lab revision modules","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Post-lab revision modules support each of the laboratory practical classes.  These modules help students appreciate the key approaches, results and conclusions of the practical class.  The modules contain embedded quiz questions with immediate feedback provided on the submitted answers. Assessment grades for this activity are awarded for completion of the modules with a minimum score of 90% for the quiz questions incorporated within the modules. The modules are to be done in the student’s own time and can be attempted multiple times to improve scores.

The mid-session exam will consist of MCQs and short answer questions related to topics covered in the first half of the course. The format is the same as the final exam. Feedback is provided through grades and model answers released to students following assessment. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e29dbec4dbf57c90be4672f5f3961992","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ea9dbec4dbf57c90be4672f5f3961991","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"aa9dbec4dbf57c90be4672f5f3961994","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online tutorials","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Online tutorials support each of the areas of physiology covered in this course.  

These tutorials serve to summarise key concepts and knowledge of lecture topics covered in the course.  Quiz questions are incorporated into the tutorials and students will receive immediate feedback on submitted answers. Assessment grades for this activity are awarded for completion of the tutorials with a minimum score of 90% for the quiz questions incorporated within the tutorials. The tutorials are to be done in student’s own time and can be attempted multiple times to improve scores.

contentlets.description:
This course introduces students to fundamental physiological principles, from basic cellular function in terms of chemical and physical principles to the operation and interaction of body systems. Although introductory in the level of content, this course in Human Physiology is comprehensive in scope covering a range of body systems from a cellular to a more integrative approach.  The areas of physiology covered in this course are excitable tissues (cell physiology), muscle, the cardiovascular system, blood and neuroscience. The course includes a substantial series of practical class experiments in which students work in small groups to conduct experiments that give a deeper insight into these specific topic areas, and an appreciation of how the results of experiments depend not only on what we measure but how we measure it.  Online self-directed activities and practical classes further support the course content and learning objectives.

B","description":"

This course introduces students to fundamental physiological principles, from basic cellular function in terms of chemical and physical principles to the operation and interaction of body systems. Although introductory in the level of content, this course in Human Physiology is comprehensive in scope covering a range of body systems from a cellular to a more integrative approach.  The areas of physiology covered in this course are temperature regulation, endocrine physiology, reproduction, respiratory physiology, kidney and body fluids, and the gastrointestinal system. The course includes a substantial series of practical class experiments in which students work in small groups to conduct experiments that give a deeper insight into these specific topic areas, and an appreciation of how the results of experiments depend not only on what we measure but how we measure it.  Online self-directed activities and practical classes further support the course content and learning objectives. 


Note: Restricted to students enrolled in the Biomedical Engineering double degree programs. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9fed3e48dbf57c90be4672f5f39619da","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"End of session exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

The end of session exam is in two Parts. Part 1 covers material from the Practical Classes throughout the whole course. Part 1 is comprised of MCQs and is worth 25%. Part 2 will consist of MCQs and short answer questions related to topics covered in the second half of the course.  Part 2 is worth 35%. Feedback is provided through a final course grade. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"97ed3e48dbf57c90be4672f5f39619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"97ed3e48dbf57c90be4672f5f39619dc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9fed3e48dbf57c90be4672f5f39619db","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2fed3e48dbf57c90be4672f5f39619e5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Post lab revision modules","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Post-lab revision modules support each of the laboratory practical classes.  These modules help students appreciate the key approaches, results and conclusions of the practical class.  The modules contain embedded quiz questions with immediate feedback provided on the submitted answers. Assessment grades for this activity are awarded for completion of the modules with a minimum score of 90% for the quiz questions incorporated within the modules. The modules are to be done in the student’s own time and can be attempted multiple times to improve scores.   

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"97ed3e48dbf57c90be4672f5f39619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9fed3e48dbf57c90be4672f5f39619db","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5bed3e48dbf57c90be4672f5f39619de","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online tutorials","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Online tutorials support each of the areas of physiology covered in this course.  

These tutorials serve to summarise key concepts and knowledge of lecture topics covered in the course.  Quiz questions are incorporated into the tutorials and students will receive immediate feedback on submitted answers. Assessment grades for this activity are awarded for completion of the tutorials with a minimum score of 90% for the quiz questions incorporated within the tutorials. The tutorials are to be done in student’s own time and can be attempted multiple times to improve scores. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"97ed3e48dbf57c90be4672f5f39619dc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"67ed3e48dbf57c90be4672f5f39619ea","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-session Theory Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

The mid-session exam will consist of MCQs and short answer questions related to topics covered in the first half of the course. The format is the same as the final exam. Feedback is provided through grades and model answers released to students following assessment.

This course introduces students to fundamental physiological principles, from basic cellular function in terms of chemical and physical principles to the operation and interaction of body systems. Although introductory in the level of content, this course in Human Physiology is comprehensive in scope covering a range of body systems from a cellular to a more integrative approach.  The areas of physiology covered in this course are temperature regulation, endocrine physiology, reproduction, respiratory physiology, kidney and body fluids, and the gastrointestinal system. The course includes a substantial series of practical class experiments in which students work in small groups to conduct experiments that give a deeper insight into these specific topic areas, and an appreciation of how the results of experiments depend not only on what we measure but how we measure it.  Online self-directed activities and practical classes further support the course content and learning objectives. 

Note: Restricted to students enrolled in the Biomedical Engineering double degree programs.

of Medicine and Health","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHSL2501 - Human Physiology A","description":"

This course introduces students to fundamental physiological principles, from basic cellular function in terms of chemical and physical principles to the operation and interaction of body systems. Although introductory in the level of content, this course in Human Physiology is comprehensive in scope covering a range of body systems from a cellular to a more integrative approach.  The areas of physiology covered in this course are excitable tissues (cell physiology), muscle, the cardiovascular system, blood and neuroscience. The course includes a substantial series of practical class experiments in which students work in small groups to conduct experiments that give a deeper insight into these specific topic areas, and an appreciation of how the results of experiments depend not only on what we measure but how we measure it.  Online self-directed activities and practical classes further support the course content and learning objectives.

Online tutorials support each of the areas of physiology covered in this course.  

These tutorials serve to summarise key concepts and knowledge of lecture topics covered in the course.  Quiz questions are incorporated into the tutorials and students will receive immediate feedback on submitted answers. Assessment grades for this activity are awarded for completion of the tutorials with a minimum score of 90% for the quiz questions incorporated within the tutorials. The tutorials are to be done in student’s own time and can be attempted multiple times to improve scores.

The end of session exam is in two Parts. Part 1 covers material from the Practical Classes throughout the whole course. Part 1 is comprised of MCQs and is worth 25%. Part 2 will consist of MCQs and short answer questions related to topics covered in the second half of the course.  Part 2 is worth 35%. Feedback is provided through a final course grade.

This course introduces students to fundamental physiological principles, from basic cellular function in terms of chemical and physical principles to the operation and interaction of body systems. Although introductory in the level of content, this course in Human Physiology is comprehensive in scope covering a range of body systems from a cellular to a more integrative approach.  The areas of physiology covered in this course are temperature regulation, endocrine physiology, reproduction, respiratory physiology, kidney and body fluids, and the gastrointestinal system. The course includes a substantial series of practical class experiments in which students work in small groups to conduct experiments that give a deeper insight into these specific topic areas, and an appreciation of how the results of experiments depend not only on what we measure but how we measure it. Online self-directed activities and practical classes further support the course content and learning objectives.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHSL3211 - Cardiovascular Physiology and Pathophysiology","description":"

This course focuses on the physiology and pathophysiology of the cardiovascular system. Unit One covers molecular and cellular aspects of cardiovascular tissues; the vascular endothelium, cardiac and smooth muscle and cell communication. Unit Two addresses systemic cardiovascular physiology, from capillary exchange, the microcirculation, the ECG, control of regional blood flow and hemodynamics, up to regulation of cardiac output and blood pressure and the function of the cardiovascular system in exercise. Unit Three focuses on the pathophysiology of the cardiovascular system, with lectures delivered by leading researchers in the fields of atherosclerosis, heart failure, hypertension and cerebrovascular disease. Lecture-based material is complemented by practical classes, on-line tutorials and problem-based learning. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e9156efa1bb5f010d5fb0fabdc4bcb05","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Poster Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will work in groups to evaluate and summarise a research article on a specific topic of cardiovascular physiology and pathophysiology and to communicate this work in a poster presentation. Groups and topics will be assigned. The poster should include: an Introduction; Methods; Data drawn from the article; and a Summary. Each group is expected to also provide a brief (5 mins) oral presentation of poster.  The task is worth20%: 15% ascribed by the examiners based on both the poster presentation and its oral defence, where each group member gets the same grade; and 5% peer-marked based on a mark given to each individual group member by fellow group members. Feedback is provided at the end of the assessment process with specific comments and marks. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"21156efa1bb5f010d5fb0fabdc4bcb07","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"61156efa1bb5f010d5fb0fabdc4bcbf5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6d156efa1bb5f010d5fb0fabdc4bcbf6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Mid-session Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

The mid-session examination is composed of multiple-choice and short answer questions covering both lecture and practical class content from approximately the first half of the course. For the practical component, students will be examined on the experimental approaches and interpretation of results. Feedback is provided through grades and model answers released to students following assessment. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"61156efa1bb5f010d5fb0fabdc4bcbf4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"61156efa1bb5f010d5fb0fabdc4bcbf5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"69156efa1bb5f010d5fb0fabdc4bcbf4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7515aefa1bb5f010d5fb0fabdc4bcb0d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Problem-Based Learning (PBL) Session","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will undertake self-directed learning using a case study or scenario relevant to cardiovascular physiology and pathophysiology.  Students will be given an outline of the problem and “clues” towards what information is required, and tutors will be available to support this activity. Students will then research the material and present their findings using both oral and written communication.  The oral presentation is to last no longer than 5 minutes and may be accompanied by slides, overheads or other visual aids. The written summary is to be no longer than a single-side A4-sized sheet. Feedback is provided at the end of the assessment process with specific comments and marks. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"21156efa1bb5f010d5fb0fabdc4bcb07","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"69156efa1bb5f010d5fb0fabdc4bcbf4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bd15aefa1bb5f010d5fb0fabdc4bcb11","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Final Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

The final examination will be a 2-hour exam composed of multiple-choice and short answer questions covering both lecture and practical class content from approximately the second half of the course. For the practical component, students will be examined on the experimental approaches and interpretation of results. Feedback is provided through grades incorporated into a final course grade released via official UNSW communication.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PHSL3221 - Endocrine, Reproductive and Developmental Physiology","description":"

This course has been developed with the aim of stimulating your interest and expanding your knowledge in the areas of endocrinology, reproduction, fertility and fetal development.  The endocrine and reproductive physiology component builds on areas covered in Physiology 1B.  The study of developmental physiology examines a wide range of organ systems and endocrine functions in the fetus, newborn and pregnant woman, and in this part of the course you will draw on your knowledge of these systems and processes from the relevant parts of Physiology 1A and 1B, and also your understanding of basic anatomy and biochemistry.

contentlets.description: This course has been developed with the aim of stimulating your interest and expanding your knowledge in the areas of endocrinology, reproduction, fertility and fetal development.  The endocrine and reproductive physiology component builds on areas covered in Physiology 1B.  The study of developmental physiology examines a wide range of organ systems and endocrine functions in the fetus, newborn and pregnant woman, and in this part of the course you will draw on your knowledge of these systems and processes from the relevant parts of Physiology 1A and 1B, and also your understanding of basic anatomy and biochemistry.
contentlets.title: Endocrine, Reproductive and Developmental Physiology
